Position the scanner between the first and second molar on the buccal side.
Align the scan area to cover 50/50 of the upper and lower teeth. Ask the patient to bite in centric occlusion.
Start the scan. After a few clicks, slowly move out the tip while scanning. Keep scanning until both arches snap into position.
Scan 3-4 teeth for perfect alignment.
FOR A FULL ARCH ONLY: Repeat the procedure on the opposite side.
Make sure you have already scanned the upper and lower arches before proceeding to the bite.

Tips:
 Avoid artifacts on the molar surface. These may result from soft tissue (lips, cheek, tongue) being scanned onto the teeth. 
Avoid excess soft tissue at the back. This may be to the distal of the last molars, or it may be large portions of sulcus to the cheek. If you scan those areas, remember to use the trim tool to clean up the scan.
Avoid bubbles of saliva being scanned onto the occlusal surface. Dry the teeth before scanning. Check the 2D live stream to see if there is a lot of white spots. 
If you should accidentally scan one or more of these artifacts, simply trim away the artifacts and rescan that area.

Evaluate the prosthesis for its distinct characteristics, considering undercuts; the depth, height, and width of the alveolar ridges; peripheral border thickness; and overall size and shape.
In Trios, select "Removables scanning."

Start the scanning process from the tuberosity area of one side of the prosthesis and proceed along the centre of the residual ridge towards the tuberosity area of the opposite side.

completely.

Rotate your scanner on a 45-degree angle and scan the
internal/buccal portion of the alveolar ridge.

This waiting period is important as it allows
for better global accuracy and for the scans to better align
themselves in the upcoming passes.

Position the scanner on the maxillary tuberosity and slowly
rotate it towards the peripheral border extension in this
region.

Start the scanning process from the first molar region,
transitioning back to the retromolar pad area of one side.

To maximize capture of the entire buccal and lingual
aspects of the impression, focus on the alveolar ridge as
well as some of the peripheral borders, if possible, for both
buccal and lingual aspects.

Stop the scanner and allow the scans to render
completely. This waiting period improves scan accuracy and alignment.
Scanning Steps
Important: Conduct a very stable and secure bite registration that inhibits the possibility of any movement of the registration as you are scanning it in your hands.

Once you have scanned the entire facial portion, commence scanning the buccal peripheral border of the mandibular arch, and transition to scanning the alveolar ridge and lingual peripheral borders in the same manner as the maxillary arch.
Continue to bring the scanner back across to the incisive papilla (midline point) area and then begin to finalize the palatal “swipe.”

Once you have captured that initial peripheral border,
continue to scan the entire peripheral border along the
maxillary arch.
Roll the opposing tuberosity peripheral border to ensure cross-arch alignment of the tuberosities.
Scan the facial/labial/buccal and occlusal surfaces of the prosthesis. This will allow for a reference in the bite scan alignment.
Once you have captured all the occlusal surfaces, do not scan the palatal portion of the prosthesis to avoid a “watertight” scan, which can create issues for the dental technician.

Proceed along the centre of the residual ridge while
rotating the scanner from side to side.

Continue in this style toward the retromolar pad on the
opposing side.
If possible, scan the entire maxillary prosthesis in the same manner as the maxillary impression scan without stopping the scanner.
Proceed to scan the entire facial portion of the maxillary arch, and transition to the lower facial.

360 Bite scan
Bite Scan (intra- or extra-orally)
Scanning steps
Scan the right bite by positioning the scanner 50% on the upper arch and 50% on the lower arch. Continue the bite scan for an additional 3 seconds after the bite has aligned.
Scan the left bite by positioning the scanner 50% on the upper arch and 50% on the lower arch. Continue the bite scan for an additional 3 seconds after the bite has aligned.

Ensure you do not have an excessive amount of registration material on the buccal aspect for the buccal bite scan. You may trim any excessive portion away with a scalpel blade to ensure you see the buccal surfaces of the posterior teeth.

Position the scanner on the retromolar pad and slowly
rotate it towards the lingual peripheral border extension
in this region.

Once you have captured that initial peripheral border,
continue to scan the entire lingual peripheral border
along the mandibular arch. Roll at the opposing retromolar
pad peripheral border to ensure cross-arch alignment.

Scan the facial/labial/buccal and occlusal surfaces of the
prosthesis. This will allow for a reference in the bite scan
alignment.

Once you have captured all the occlusal surfaces, do not scan
the lingual flange portion of the prosthesis to avoid a “watertight” scan.

It is ideal to have one third of the scanner out capturing
the ridge portion from steps 1-5 during this entire scan, if possible.
You are scanning a narrow area, so the scanner should be moved in such a way that new images are easily and accurately stitched to the already captured surface.
Remove any excess impression material on the facial, occlusal, and lingual aspects of the prosthesis to avoid miss-alignment of scans and inaccuracies in occlusion.

Tips:
After you have captured the internal alveolar ridge width and depth, allow these scans to render. 
When you begin to re-scan the peripheral borders, keep the 2D live image, so that at least one third of the window is positioned over the already aligned alveolar ridge scans and no more than two thirds is positioned over the new scans.
You are scanning a wide area, so the scanner should be moved in such a way that new images are easily and accurately stitched to the already captured surface

These steps can be accomplished in a single pass, but this is often challenging. If you are new to scanning reference dentures, we recommend working in stages. 
In this sequence which side is scanned first is of no reference and you can
develop a process that works best for you

General Tips Before Scanning: 1. Camera grip: Hold the camera using a pen or pencil grip, resting the black area on the fleshy pad between your thumb and fingers. Change the lens direction by rolling the sleeve or flipping the camera over.
2. Viewing during scanning: As a beginner, it's more natural to look in the mouth while scanning. However, as you gain experience, you may prefer looking at the screen, especially for capturing missing data.
3. Scanning enough: The goal is to capture all critical areas with minimal duplication. Overscanning slows down processes and increases file size. Avoid rescanning areas already captured.
4. Managing scan data: Take a simple framework scan and then stop. Zoom in to identify holes in critical areas and fill those in. Holes in non-critical areas are acceptable. 5. Quadrant or full-arch scan: Decide if you need a quadrant (to the midline) for single restorations or a full-arch scan for bridges, clear aligners, splints, and digital denture preliminary scans.

When you select an Abutment, TRIOS software automatically adds an extra scan step to the workflow. The Emergence profile step can be deselected by clicking it, if you do not wish to scan the gingiva around the healing cap.

In selecting the emergence profile scan, you will have to perform 5 scans: lower arch, upper arch, prep area, scan body, and occlusion. It is recommended that you start by scanning the opposing arch first.

Start with the molar occlusal surface, wait 3-5 clicks, then move towards the canine while the scanning captures the occlusal surface. When you reach the canine, turn slowly lingual, taking care first of areas where soft tissue may interfere with the scan.
When the scanning is complete, you can inspect the result and prepare the scan for trimming unnecessary parts. If an important area is missing, simply start scanning the area.
Scan the buccal side by moving mesial, and stop the scanning when the canine has been scanned.

Roll the scanner 60-90 degres to the lingual side. Use the tip to keep the tongue away. Go along the lingual surface until you reach the last molar. Slowly roll over the lingual surface until you reach the last molar going towards the buccal side.

When you have finished scanning the opposing arch, it is recommended to press Next to move on to scanning the implant arch. Alternatively, you can move on to the next step by using the hands-free method.

Start with the molar occlusal surface, wait 3-5 clicks, then move towards the canine while the scanning captures the occlusal surface. When you reach the canine, turn slowly lingual, taking care first of areas where soft tissue may interfere with the scan.
When the scanning is complete, you can inspect the result and prepare the scan for trimming unnecessary parts. If an important area is missing, simply start scanning the area.
Scan the buccal side by moving mesial, and stop the scanning when the canine has been scanned.

Roll the scanner 60-90 degres to the lingual side. Use the tip to keep the tongue away. Go along the lingual surface until you reach the last molar. Slowly roll over the lingual surface until you reach the last molar going towards the buccal side.

You will be promted to mark the tooth. Click on the Mark Tooth option from the left-hand side menu, then click the center of the tooth on the occlusal surface for both abutment teeth. 
At this point you may receive a warning informing you about missing scan data near the preparation area, which means you may have to scan again in those areas.

At this step you can use the Lock surface tool, which can be found in the menu on the left-hand side of the screen.
Now you can paint over the area of the scan which you wish to lock, which means that in the next scanning steps no further data will be collected from this area. So, if the gingiva collapses after you remove the healing cap you will still have a good scan of the emergence profile.

To take an HD Photo of the emergence profile, select it from the left-hand side of the screen or select it from the navigation wheel. Then tap the scanner button to start taking a photo. The green box means that the photo is in focus and if you tap the scanner button again the HD photo will be taken.

To perform a shade measurement, you will be prompted to Add a shade to the scan by clicking an area which is free from blue overlay. To remove an area of blue overlay, place the scan tip over the area and re-scan to collect more information. The blue overlay will disappear as you do so.

The software will automatically remove that area of the scan that was marked previously and replace it with data as you scan.
It is important to scan only the scan body and the closest area to ensure good coverage of the scan body. Complete the following scan sequence.
Start the scanner pointing at a neighboring tooth. Once the scanner has picked up the position, slowly move to the scan body and circle around it to scan it from all angles.
It is especially important to cover the upper third of the scanbody to make it possible for the laboratory to recognize the correct position.

Scanning the occlusion is the final scanning stage of the workflow. Remember to remove the scan body and ask the patient to bite and then scan the occlusion following the official scanning strategy. The bite will snap into place. Now you can move on to the validation stage of the workflow by selecting it from the workflow bar at the top of the screen.
Tip: Pull out the cheek a bit with the scanner tip. Not touching sensitive gingiva will increase patient comfort.
Tip: Ask the patient to bite in centric occlusion.
Tip: The scanner tip will hold out the cheek.
Tip: Make sure the patient gets the same bite position again.
Tip: Continue scanning even if the scan snaps together before scanning 3-4 teeth.

When you click the direction button, the software will automatically suggest an optimal insertion direction.

You can make adjustments to this by rotating the scan so that you can see all the preparation area, then click the Use View button. You can inspect to see if there are any undercuts, which would be highlighted in red.

There are some important things to make sure of during the inspection: 1. Verify that the scans cover the entire oral cavity, including all teeth and relevant anatomical structures. 
2. Ensure there are no gaps or missing sections in the scan data. 
3. Pay attention to the accuracy of the margins and interproximal areas in the scans. The margins should be well-defined and clearly distinguishable, while the interproximal spaces should be adequately captured without overlapping or distortion.  
4. Look for any artifacts, such as reflections, shadows, or scanning errors, that may have affected the quality of the scans.

Recommendations for bite scans: 
Use suitable material to record the bite.
Ensure a stable jaw position with a gauge or jig in the therapeutic bite position. 
Leave a minimum of 3 millimeters of draw space between the arches. 
Leave a minimum of 5 millimeters of clearance between the two opposing anteriors.
Make sure the scan exposes the canine region and the distal last teeth.

Common Issues in Bite Scanning:            1. Incomplete bite registration: If the bite registration is not captured completely, such as missing certain teeth or inadequate coverage of the occlusal surfaces. 
2. Incorrect bite position: If the patient's bite is not correctly positioned in the therapeutic or desired position during the bite registration. 
3. Interference from soft tissue or tongue: The presence of soft tissue or the tongue between the upper and lower arches during the bite registration can cause inaccuracies. 
4. Patient discomfort or movement: Patients may experience discomfort or involuntary movement during the bite registration process.

General Tips Before Scanning: 1. Camera grip: Hold the camera using a pen or pencil grip, resting the black area on the fleshy pad between your thumb and fingers. Change the lens direction by rolling the sleeve or flipping the camera over.
2. Viewing during scanning: As a beginner, it's more natural to look in the mouth while scanning. However, as you gain experience, you may prefer looking at the screen, especially for capturing missing data.
3. Scanning enough: The goal is to capture all critical areas with minimal duplication. Overscanning slows down processes and increases file size. Avoid rescanning areas already captured.
4. Managing scan data: Take a simple framework scan and then stop. Zoom in to identify holes in critical areas and fill those in. Holes in non-critical areas are acceptable.

Lingual swipe: Begin by positioning the scanner on the lingual (inside) surface of the lower jaw. Start scanning from one side and move the scanner in a sweeping motion towards the opposite side, capturing the lingual surfaces of the teeth.

Click on the margin line icon to set the margin. With a post and core you are required to drag the margin line into the suitable position. Do this by using the cursor to draw a line, following the sharpest edge. Pay attention not to set the margin line too short or too far. You can always turn off colors and zoom in and rotate the scan to examine the margin line from all sides. When satisfied click Done.

You have completed case setup. Would you like to proceed to scan strategy guidance?
By default, you will start with scanning the lower jaw. However, you can start with the upper if you wish.
Scanning-Start-Lower
Start on the occlusal surface of the last molar and then move slowly toward the incisors.
Lower-occlusal-scan
Now, roll the scanner toward the lingual side and move along the whole arch.
Lower-Lingual-Scan
Once you reach the last molar, rotate the scanner to the buccal side and repeat the process of moving along the whole arch.
Lower-Buccal-Scan
After the whole arch has been scanned, inspect the model.
Inspect the model
Move on to scanning the upper jaw.
Scanning-Start-Upper
Again, start with the occlusal surface of the last molar.
Upper-Occlusal-Scan
Roll the scanner over to the buccal side, scan along the arch to the last molar on the opposite side.
Upper-Buccal-Scan
Rotate the scanner to the palatal side and repeat the scanning of the whole arch.
Upper-Palatal-scan
Palate-Scan
If you need to scan the palate, position the scanner behind the incisors and slowly go from side to side across the palate in the distal direction.
Inspect the scan before moving on to scanning the occlusion.
Scan-Inspection
Scan is done and ready to be sent to the lab
Make sure that the mirror in tip of the scanner is facing downwards.
The scanning procedure for the lower jaw consists of three swipes: occlusal, lingual, and buccal.
Make sure to slightly wiggle the scanner over both sides over the centrals to capture all data and then continue until you reach the last molar on the opposite side.
Use the navigation button, which is the second button furthest from the tip, to inspect the model without touching the screen. Re-scan if any data is missing. Trim away any the unnecessary parts.

To move on to the upper jaw, you can use the navigation button to select Next or the icon. The scanning procedure for the upper jaw is different as it consists of three swipes: occlusal, buccal, and palatal. Make sure that the mirror in tip of the scanner is facing upwards.
Repeat the action of wiggling the scanner over the central teeth and continue moving along the arch until the last molar.
If necessary, you can trim it and rescan any areas that weren’t captured correctly.
